item.title: Rags, Tea and Advice as Syrians Fret Over Cease-Fire
item.media:description: Castello Road in Aleppo, Syria, on Friday.
item.description: As the Muslim holiday of Eid al-Adha wound down, Syrians squeezed in precious time with family and friends as the sound of explosions signaled a truce may be fraying.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Violence Flares With 3 Attacks on Israelis in Jerusalem and West Bank
item.description: Three Arabs who tried to attack Israelis were shot and killed, shattering a relative lull and renewing fears of a wider conflict.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Inspired by the U.S., West Africans Wield Smartphones to Fight Police Abuse
item.media:description: In a scene caught on cellphone video, a police officer in Ivory Coast killed an unarmed theft suspect.
item.description: Citizens are increasingly deploying social media in nations where corruption and abuse by security forces sometimes occur with few repercussions.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and JAIME YAYA BARRY

item.title: South Sudan Rejects Report on Leaders’ Wealth
item.description: The government has denounced a report that accuses the leaders on both sides of the country’s civil war of stoking violence to amass illegal wealth.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Turks See Purge as Witch Hunt of ‘Medieval’ Darkness
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey in Ankara last month. Two months after a failed military coup, a wide-scale purge led by Mr. Erdogan has reached witch-hunt proportions, according to a growing chorus of critics.
item.media:credit: Turkish Presidential Office, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: Critics say the wrong book or bank account, even reading the wrong newspaper or posting on Twitter, could lead to being fired or thrown in jail.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO, CEYLAN YEGINSU and SAFAK TIMUR
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: A Two-Mile Beer Pipeline Carries Belgium’s Lifeblood to Be Bottled
item.description: One of Belgium’s oldest breweries, in the narrow streets of medieval Bruges, solved a transportation problem and a avoided a move from the city center.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN and MILAN SCHREUER
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

item.title: European Leaders Debate Proposals for Closer Military Ties
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany spoke to reporters at a European Union summit meeting in Bratislava, Slovakia, on Friday.
item.description: Amid high levels of anti-European Union sentiment across the Continent, European nations are considering greater coordination among their armed forces.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER

item.title: Bombing at Pakistan Mosque Kills at Least 22
item.description: A splinter group of the Pakistani Taliban claimed the attack, saying it was a crackdown against pro-government residents in the Mohmand tribal area.
item.dc:creator: ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: Mumbai Journal: Indians, Some Seeking Brighter Fortunes, Celebrate Vibrant Ganesh Festival
item.media:description: A procession with a giant idol of the elephant-headed god Ganesh headed toward the coast in Mumbai, India, on Thursday. The statue will be immersed in the ocean, marking the final day of the Ganesh festival.
item.description: A festival to worship the elephant-headed god began in 19th-century Mumbai as an anticolonial protest, but it has since spread across the country.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND

item.title: Canada Today: Searchers Find a Shipwreck, and Conservatives Seek a Leader
item.media:description: An image of the Terror stuck in ice during an 1836-7 Arctic expedition. The ship was trapped 10 months, but made it back to England and returned to service. The wreck of the Terror, last seen in 1845 on the Sir John Franklin Arctic expedition, was found this month.
item.description: A weekly roundup of news and events with a focus on the True North.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Mexican Protesters Demand Ouster of President Enrique Peña Nieto
item.media:description: Protesters in Mexico City on Thursday called on President Enrique Peña Nieto to resign. With each crisis, the government “simply loses any notion of dignity and capacity to rule,” one demonstrator said.
item.description: Hours before the start of Independence Day celebrations, a mostly young crowd marched in the capital to express anger over scandals and a weakening economy.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: U.N. Meeting a Farewell for Obama, and a Dress Rehearsal for Clinton
item.media:description: President Obama speaking on the opening day of the General Assembly at the United Nations in New York last year.
item.media:credit: Michael Appleton for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Obama’s last General Assembly as president is a return to the diplomatic stage for his preferred successor, who will meet with world leaders she already knows.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: Nigeria Describes 3 Failed Negotiations With Boko Haram on Kidnapped Girls
item.media:description: A screen grab made last month from a video shows a man described as a Boko Haram fighter with a group of girls said to be some of those abducted from a school in Chibok, Nigeria, in 2014.
item.description: More than 200 schoolgirls were kidnapped by the terrorist group in July 2015, and three times government negotiations have failed.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and CHRIS STEIN

item.title: Carlo Azeglio Ciampi, Former Italian Prime Minister, Dies at 95
item.media:description: Mr. Ciampi with Pope Benedict XVI in Rome in 2005. He served as both prime minister and president of Italy.
item.description: Mr. Ciampi, a respected economist, led the country during a turbulent period and helped usher in the euro.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Attacks in a British Town Highlight a Debate Over Ethnic Tensions
item.media:description: A memorial where Arkadiusz Jozwik, a Polish immigrant, was attacked in Harlow, England.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Some warn that the vote to leave the E.U. unleashed latent racism, while others caution that not every alcohol-fueled altercation has its basis in racial and ethnic differences.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: U.S. Special Operations Forces Arrive in Syria to Advise Turks in ISIS Fight
item.description: The Pentagon on Friday stressed that about three dozen Special Operations troops would serve in an “advise and assist” capacity.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Diane James Is Elected to Lead UKIP, a Force Behind the ‘Brexit’ Vote
item.media:description: Diane James, the newly elected leader of the U.K Independence Party, with her immediate predecessor, Nigel Farage, at the party’s conference in Bournemouth, England, on Friday.
item.description: The party, which is in disarray and fighting to be relevant after this summer’s referendum, chose a businesswoman and staunch critic of the European Union.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Finding His Place, Reluctantly, in the Tribe of Judaism
item.media:description: Philippe Sands in Edinburgh. His discoveries became the core of a book about his family, the Holocaust and the Nuremberg trials.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: For Philippe Sands, the story of the Nuremberg trials and the development of human rights intersects with his family history in painful ways.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
East West Street: On the Origins of Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity (Book)
My Nazi Legacy (What Our Fathers Did) (Movie)

item.title: Edward Snowden Says Disclosures Bolstered Individual Privacy
item.description: Speaking from Russia to a session of the Athens Democracy Forum, the whistle-blower said he would maintain his focus on U.S. surveillance policies.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: India Detains Kashmiri Activist Who Was to Address U.N. Group
item.media:description: Indian forces on patrol this during a protest in Srinagar, Kashmir. More than 70 people, most of them civilians, have been killed since unrest broke out on July 9.
item.description: Khurram Parvez was set to speak to the Human Rights Council about protests in Kashmir when he was taken into “preventive custody.”
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: Letter From Europe: Another Russian Émigré Dies Mysteriously, but It’s a Different Britain
item.media:description: Alexander V. Litvinenko in November 2006. He died after ingesting green tea laced with radioactive polonium 210.
item.description: After a similar 2006 death, London expelled four diplomats and broke some ties with Moscow. These days, the calculations of realpolitik have changed.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Turkish Cleric, Accused in Coup Plot, Calls Crackdown ‘Dark Pages’ in History
item.media:description: Fethullah Gulen, a Muslim cleric living in self-imposed exile, at his headquarters in Saylorsburg, Pa., the day after a coup attempt against the government of Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
item.media:credit: Charles Mostoller for The New York Times
item.description: The cleric, Fethullah Gulen, who lives in Pennsylvania, spoke for the first time since Turkey’s government formally asked the United States to arrest him.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Obama, Pressing Senators, Delays Veto of Bill Exposing Saudis to 9/11 Suits
item.media:description: President Obama with Adel al-Jubeir, the Saudi foreign minister, during a trip to the kingdom in April. Mr. Jubeir on Thursday spoke with Senator Lindsey Graham, the South Carolina Republican, to reiterate Saudi concerns about the bill.
item.description: The president hopes to tap into an unusual well of buyer’s remorse among senators after facing what had appeared to be an inevitable veto override.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER STEINHAUER, JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: Canadian Kevin Garratt, Held 2 Years on Spy Charges in China, Is Released
item.media:description: Kevin Garratt, who was held in China for two years on suspicion of spying, hugging his wife, Julia Dawn Garratt, after he returned to Vancouver, Canada, on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Courtesy of the Garratt Family, via Reuters
item.description: The case of Mr. Garratt, who worked with a charity that provided food to North Koreans, had dampened relations between Canada and China.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Department Stores Find Room to Grow in Canada
item.media:description: Escalators at one of two Toronto outlets of Holt Renfrew, the luxury department store.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: Department stores are closing outlets in the United States, but Canada is looking like a lucrative frontier for some, including Nordstrom.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN and RACHEL ABRAMS

item.title: Streets and Skies Suddenly Quiet, Syrians Watch Cease-Fire With Unease
item.media:description: A cafe in the government-held part of Aleppo on Tuesday.
item.description: President Bashar al-Assad’s supporters and opponents alike share misgivings. They know the truce was negotiated over their heads, and they do not know the details.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Obama Plans Another Appeal for Trans-Pacific Partnership Trade Deal
item.description: The president will host a bipartisan group of backers of the Trans-Pacific Partnership in the Oval Office on Friday, hoping to underscore its benefits.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: The Interpreter: The Surprising Science of Cease-Fires: Even Failures Can Help Peace
item.media:description: Children on a carousel in Douma, Syria, on Tuesday, the second day of Eid al-Adha. Cease-fires can create something like a virtuous cycle, but there is also a flip side: the vicious cycle.
item.description: Cease-fires can create something like a virtuous cycle, making future pauses more likely. But beware the flip side: the vicious cycle.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: Russia’s Opposition, While Repressed, May Be Its Own Worst Enemy
item.media:description: Maria Baronova, a candidate for Parliament from the Open Russia movement, spoke on Thursday to a crowd in Moscow.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: The chances are slim that opponents of President Vladimir V. Putin, divided and largely ineffective, will make gains in Sunday’s parliamentary elections.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Wing Flap Confirmed as Malaysia Airlines Debris
item.media:description: Officials inspecting a piece of debris found off the coast of Tanzania this summer, more than two years after Malaysia Airlines’ Flight 370 disappeared. The Australian Transport Safety Bureau matched the piece’s serial number and confirmed that it is from the missing plane.
item.description: The Boeing 777-200 part, found on a Tanzanian island, came from Flight 370, which mysteriously disappeared in March 2014, officials said.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Wheels: A Tweedy Gathering of Vintage Cars at Goodwood
item.media:description: Mechanics work on vintage cars at the Goodwood Revival in Chichester, England.
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Dalziel for The New York Times
item.description: The annual event in England has a very British flair and tries to re-create the postwar automotive atmosphere up to 1966.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN WILLIAMS

item.title: Obama’s Move to End Myanmar Sanctions Promises a Lift for Its Economy
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, Myanmar’s de facto leader, in Washington on Wednesday.
item.description: The decision could fuel the growth of smaller businesses in the Southeast Asian country, even as individuals and companies currently blacklisted also prosper.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Syria Is Delaying Aid Deliveries in Violation of Cease-Fire, U.N. Says
item.media:description: Staffan de Mistura, the United Nations special envoy to Syria, warned in Geneva on Thursday that the delivery of humanitarian aid that was part of the Syria cease-fire deal had not taken place.
item.description: A United Nations official said the Syrian government had not issued authorization for aid convoys to pass checkpoints.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: E.U. Leaders, Struggling to Respond to Crises, Gather in Slovakia
item.media:description: Thousands demonstrated in London in July against Britain’s decision to leave the European Union. Members of the bloc are divided over how to handle negotiations with London.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Representatives of 27 member nations — all but Britain, which voted in June to leave the bloc — remain divided over migration, security and the economy.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte Ordered Philippine Killings, Professed Hit Man Testifies
item.media:description: Investigators examining the body of a victim thought to have been killed by a gunman for hire in the Philippine city of Caloocan, a part of greater Manila, in August.
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.description: A spokesman denied the charges against President Duterte, who was accused in a Senate hearing of presiding over 1,000 killings as mayor of Davao City.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR and MIKE IVES
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: India Prevents Kashmiri Activist From Traveling to U.N. Meeting
item.media:description: Protesters in Srinagar, the capital of the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir, on Tuesday.
item.description: The activist, Khurram Parvez, was to submit a report to the United Nations Human Rights Council on the situation in the Indian-controlled portion of Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Jammu Kashmir Coalition of Civil Society

item.title: Pauline Hanson, Australian Senator, Urges End to Muslim Immigration
item.description: Newly elected to the Senate, Ms. Hanson, the leader of the One Nation party, also called for a ban on the burqa.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese Tycoon Behind Grindr Will Pay $1.14 Billion in Divorce
item.description: The transfer of shares to Zhou Yahui’s wife is the latest example of a split affecting the fortunes of a Chinese company.
item.dc:creator: EMILY FENG
item.category: Beijing Kunlun World Wide Technology Share Co Ltd

item.title: Train Crash in Pakistan Kills at Least 4
item.description: A freight train was sitting idle after it had run over a man on the tracks, a senior official was quoted as saying by the news media, when a commuter train smashed into its rear.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Japan’s Main Opposition Party Elects First Female Leader
item.description: Renho Murata, chosen as head of the Democratic Party, became the third woman to take up a prominent political job in Japan in less than two months.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Hinkley Point Nuclear Plant Will Go Ahead, Britain Says
item.description: The project, financed in part with French and Chinese investment, had been postponed in July, angering its international partners.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.category: Hinkley Point C Nuclear Power Plant (England)

item.title: What in the World: In Britain’s Parliament, a Crowded House Bursting With Lords
item.media:description: A parliamentary session this month at the House of Lords in London. There is no limit on membership, and members generally serve for life.
item.description: Efforts to overhaul the House of Lords, reduce its membership or abolish it altogether have produced more noise than fundamental change.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: What in the World: What’s Hebrew for ‘When in the Course of Human Events’?
item.media:description: The Declaration of Independence begins with Thomas Jefferson’s famous phrase “when in the course of human events” — and so did an early draft of Israel’s founding document.
item.description: Early drafts of Israel’s founding document borrowed heavily from Thomas Jefferson in the Declaration of Independence, among other famous writings.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: So Much Land, Too Few Russians
item.description: A tide of Chinese migration to a corner of Russia’s Far East is the latest example of a history that bends Moscow toward autocracy.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL KHODARKOVSKY
item.category: Ministry for the Development of the Far East (Russia)

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Can a Post-Coup Turkey Get Along with Europe?
item.media:description: An image of Fethullah Gulen during a July rally in Istanbul in support of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
item.description: Both sides have an obligation to try to salvage their relationship.
item.dc:creator: IVAN KRASTEV
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Venezuela: The Opposition Mobilizes for the Presidential Referendum
item.media:description: Venezuelans marching this month in Caracas in protest against the government.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: The country needs to hammer out a democratic transition, but success is unlikely if mass demonstrations are halted.
item.dc:creator: FRANCISCO SUNIAGA

item.title: Throwing Stones and Slaughtering Sheep at the Hajj
item.media:description: Outside a slaughterhouse on the outskirts of Mecca, men hang around looking to work for tips, paid in cash or in chunks of meat.
item.description: Diaa Hadid, a Times correspondent making the Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca, picked up tips on how to practice some of the rites and rituals of the hajj.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: At the Hajj, Facing Islam’s Inconsistent Embrace of Women
item.media:description: Women at the hajj, clockwise from left: on Ajyad Street, one of the main thoroughfares leading to the Grand Mosque in Mecca; Indonesian women rested on a sidewalk in the tent city of Mina, where nearly 2 million pilgrims slept for three days as part of their hajj rites; and the Times correspondent Diaa Hadid during the hajj.
item.description: Our reporter, on her first hajj, says she “was at once frustrated by Islam’s nitpicky strictures on women’s dress and embraced by its warm sisterhood.”
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Notebook: How Many Guns Did the U.S. Lose Track of in Iraq and Afghanistan? Hundreds of Thousands.
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers after receiving new rifles from U.S. forces in Baghdad in May 2007.
item.description: A new study shows how the American military failed at the soldier’s most basic responsibility: keeping track of firearms.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: How Russia Often Benefits When Julian Assange Reveals the West’s Secrets
item.media:description: Julian Assange looking out from the Ecuadorean Embassy in London in February. Having lived there for four years, he is increasingly isolated.
item.description: American officials say Mr. Assange and WikiLeaks probably have no direct ties to Russian intelligence services. But the agendas of WikiLeaks and the Kremlin have often dovetailed.
item.dc:creator: JO BECKER, STEVEN ERLANGER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
